item.title: Covid: Food workers given exemption from isolation rules
item.description: Key parts of the food industry move to daily testing after isolating workers led to supply shortages.

item.title: Olympics opening ceremony to begin later
item.description: With the opening ceremony set for Friday, BBC Sport previews the Tokyo 2020 Olympics - a Games like no other.

item.title: People splash out on food and drink for Euro 2020
item.description: Retail sales rose by 0.5% as millions stocked up on food and drink to watch the football tournament.

item.title: Daily contact testing in schools cuts absences, study finds
item.description: A study in 200 English secondary schools and colleges found very few infections in close contacts of cases.

item.title: Covid-19: Isolation exemption, and daily pupil testing 'cuts' absences
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Friday morning.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Eight-week gap seen as sweet spot for Pfizer jab antibodies
item.description: Spacing out doses boosts antibody levels, say researchers - who suggest eight weeks as the "sweet spot".

item.title: Child winter respiratory illness on rise in summer
item.description: Parents are warned to look out for signs of RSV, after lockdown disrupted its normal winter spread.

item.title: 'Ghost school' with no students for a second year
item.description: English language schools warn they are on the "brink of collapse" after two summers without students.

item.title: Government rules out searching Matt Hancock's private emails
item.description: Matt Hancock was among four ministers who used their personal email accounts for official business.

item.title: Road planners able to ignore climate change, campaigners claim
item.description: Government guidelines mean road planners can effectively ignore climate change, campaigners say.

item.title: Sarm Heslop: Missing woman's parents still have hope
item.description: Four months after she vanished, it is still not known what happened to Sarm Heslop.

item.title: Pontyclun crash: Six in hospital after car hits people outside pub
item.description: Police believe the driver of the car suffered a "medical episode" just before the crash.

item.title: The Papers: 'Ping peril' and pupils isolating 'needless'
item.description: Concerns over workers and school children being told to isolate continue to dominate the front pages.

item.title: Tusker Rock's shipwrecks graveyard captured in art project
item.description: Photographer Peter Britton wants his project to stand as a legacy to those lost to Tusker Rock.

item.title: The cost of hosting the Olympics
item.description: Holding the world's biggest sporting event comes with a hefty price tag

item.title: Emily Ratajkowski sponsors Bantry Basketball Club in County Cork
item.description: Emily Ratajkowski buys kit for Bantry's U15 and U16 teams, setting Snapchat "on fire".

item.title: The refugee athlete who lost his mum to Covid
item.description: Abdullah Sediqi, 24, is competing at the Tokyo Games in her honour.

item.title: Pilot praises RAF Lakenheath plane spotter for saving his life
item.description: Ian Simpson alerts an airbase after seeing sparks and flames coming from the rear of a jet.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: I beat an Olympian... when I was younger
item.description: Radio 1 Newsbeat speaks to people who can boast they once beat some of the current Team GB.

item.title: Fashion for Crocs continues to break records
item.description: The chunky shoe's sales nearly doubled in the three months to the end of June compared with last year.

item.title: Dawn Butler thrown out of Commons for PM lie accusation
item.description: Dawn Butler breaks parliamentary rules by accusing Boris Johnson of lying.

item.title: Climate change, a coalmine and a town that needs jobs
item.description: In Cumbria, environmental concerns come into conflict with economic hopes.

item.title: Parents' fears over sexting and abuse among teenagers
item.description: A mother and a father reveal their shock at learning of their children's experiences of online sex.

item.title: Coronavirus: Was US money used to fund risky research in China?
item.description: What's the row about virus research in China between a prominent Republican and Dr Anthony Fauci?

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Katarina Johnson-Thompson's battles with injury & self-doubt in pursuit of Olympic gold
item.description: How Katarina Johnson-Thompson tore up everything to claim world gold and will have to upset the odds once more to win in Tokyo.

item.title: What does a future-proofed home look like?
item.description: The technology exists to make homes more resilient to extreme weather, but it can be expensive.

item.title: Amy Winehouse: Could there be new music on the way?
item.description: Ten years after her death, Amy's parents say they want fans to hear CDs of her unreleased material.

item.title: Trading sex for cosmetic surgery in Mexico's narco capital
item.description: The influence of narcos has caused many women to undergo cosmetic surgery in Mexico's Sinaloa state.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Japanese artists reimagine countries as anime samurai
item.description: The creators have used the flags of competing nations as inspiration to design Japanese warriors.

item.title: 'I thought rape isn't something that happens to men'
item.description: Support charities say male victims of sexual assault sometimes feel their experiences don't count.

item.title: Eating disorders: The terrible impact of the pandemic on the young
item.description: Admissions soared during the pandemic, and NHS bosses warn they are running out of beds.

item.title: Post Office scandal: What the Horizon saga is all about
item.description: The background to the cases of sub-postmasters whose convictions were based on evidence from faulty IT.

item.title: Rugby League World Cup withdrawal 'premature', says Australia players' union
item.description: Australia and New Zealand's decision to pull out of the Rugby League World Cup was "premature", according to Australia's players' union.

item.title: The Hundred: Oval Invincibles secure entertaining win over Manchester Originals in first men's game
item.description: Oval Invincibles edge out Manchester Originals in an entertaining first men's match of The Hundred at The Oval.

item.title: The Hundred - Oval Invincibles v Manchester Originals: Watch highlights of the first men's Hundred match
item.description: Watch the best moments from the opening match of the men's Hundred, as Oval Invincibles beat the Manchester Originals.

item.title: Dream move fulfils promise to grandma - Podolski set for debut with boyhood club
item.description: Lukas Podolski is set for his competitive debut for boyhood club Gornik Zabrze and BBC Sport looks at how he is fulfilling a family promise.

item.title: The Hundred: Shane Warne on coaching London Spirit and working with Eoin Morgan
item.description: Shane Warne talks to BBC Sport about how he will coach London Spirit in The Hundred and his fascinating partnership with captain Eoin Morgan.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Adam Peaty meets Reece Parkinson to talk cars, fatherhood & staying undefeated.
item.description: British swimmer Adam Peaty meets BBC Radio 1's Reece Parkinson to talk cars, fatherhood and staying undefeated at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Kye Whyte, BMX rider - from naughty kid to becoming an Olympian
item.description: BMX rider Kye Whyte talks going from a naughty kid growing up in Peckham to the Olympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Dina Asher-Smith opens up on body image & tackling racism in sport
item.description: Dina Asher-Smith opens up about life on and off the track with friend and Radio 1 DJ Clara Amfo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Hannah Mills and rower Mohamed Sbihi to be Team GB flag bearers
item.description: Sailor Hannah Mills and rower Mohamed Sbihi are chosen to carry the flag for Great Britain at Friday's Tokyo Olympics opening ceremony.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: BBC TV, radio and online coverage - times and channels
item.description: Full listings and coverage channels for the Tokyo Olympics across BBC TV, BBC iPlayer, BBC radio and online.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Ten tear-jerking moments from the Olympics past
item.description: It isn't always the big names and blue-riband events that create all the memories. Here are 10 times the Olympics has set spines tingling and tears flowing

item.title: Olympic football: Men's players to watch at Tokyo 2020
item.description: Here is the lowdown on the biggest names and brightest stars looking to shine this summer in the men's Olympic football tournament.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Katie Archibald on her gold medal dreams & pressure
item.description: Cyclist Katie Archibald tells BBC Sport about her dreams of another gold medal and the pressure of helping Laura Kenny become Britain's best.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Top 10 days for Team GB at the Olympics
item.description: BBC Sport selects the top 10 unmissable days for Team GB fans at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: How quiet rebel Naomi Osaka is changing Japan
item.description: Naomi Osaka's relationship with Japan has not always been easy, but change rarely is. How the face of the Games is changing the host nation.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Projected medal table, Team GB medallists and international stars to watch
item.description: Data company Gracenote forecasts the Tokyo 2020 medal table, Team GB medallists and the international stars to watch.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Tom Daley on triumph, trauma and his likely last shot at gold
item.description: The 'baby' of Beijing has become a father, a husband and an LGBTQ+ spokesperson. Tom Daley has perhaps one final shot at Olympic gold.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: What to expect in the women's football tournament
item.description: The Olympic Games are almost here so what can we expect at the women's football tournament?

item.title: What are the new sports at the Tokyo Olympic Games?
item.description: With 34 new events in total added to the Tokyo Olympic programme, BBC Sport takes a look at what's new.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the NHS test-and-trace system and app work?
item.description: The contact tracing app could be changed to make it less sensitive, so it sends fewer alerts.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: What are the Delta, Gamma, Beta and Alpha Covid variants?
item.description: UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant first identified in India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics begin formally on Friday, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The progress made in vaccinating the country's adult population, as more than 46 million people have received at least one dose.

item.title: Care homes worst hit by Covid – search the data
item.description: Figures from Care Quality Commission lay out the pandemic's 'devastating impact' on care homes in England.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: There has been confusion about who needs to self-isolate and which workers might be able to avoid it.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Vaccine experts recommend that a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Fully jabbed adults don't have to self-isolate after visiting amber-list countries - except France.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.
